title-group.article-title: On Predicting Stock Returns with Nearly Integrated Explanatory Variables*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2004 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: Statistical inference in predictive regressions depends critically on the stochastic properties of the posited explanatory variable, in particular, its order of integration. Confidence intervals computed for the largest autoregressive root of many explanatory variables commonly used in predictive regressions, including the dividend yield, the book‐to‐market ratio, the short‐term rate of interest, and the term and default spreads, confirm uncertainty surrounding these variables' order of integration. We investigate the effects of this uncertainty on inferences drawn in predictive regressions. Once this uncertainty is accounted for, contrary to previous evidence, we find reliable evidence of predictability at shorter rather than at longer horizons.

fn.p: An earlier version of this paper was presented at the University of Verona, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, and the European meetings of the Financial Management Association. The comments and suggestions of an anonymous referee are greatly appreciated. We, however, are responsible for any remaining errors. Contact the corresponding author atwtorous@anderson.ucla.edu.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In a predictive regression, rates of return are regressed against the lagged values of a stochastic explanatory variable. Examples include, among others, regressing common stock returns against the dividend yield (Fama and French1988), regressing bond returns against the spread between long‐term and short‐term yields on bonds (Keim and Stambaugh1986), and regressing changes in spot exchange rates against the spread between forward and spot exchange rates (Fama1984). The predictability of rates of return using lagged stochastic explanatory variables has been interpreted as evidence of market inefficiency or, alternatively, as evidence of time‐varying expected returns in financial markets (see Fama1991for a review).

Extant research (for example, Stambaugh1999) assumes a predictive regression's stochastic explanatory variable is stationary. However, the assumption of stationarity is unsatisfactory for many explanatory variables commonly used in predictive regressions. For example, as argued by Roll (2002), rational expectations can imply nonstationarity in explanatory variables that are functions of asset prices, such as the dividend yield and the book‐to‐market ratio. In particular, since rational expectations must not be expected to change, an expectation about a future quantity must follow a random walk if innovations in expectations are independent and indentically distributed. Since asset prices are functions of expectations about future quantities, explanatory variables which are functions of asset prices also follow a random walk.

We demonstrate that inference in predictive regressions depends critically on the assumed stochastic properties of the posited explanatory variable. It is well known that dramatically different null distributions of test statistics result when the regressor is assumed to be integrated, that is, when the regressor follows a random walk (see, for example, Phillips1987b). Unfortunately, in practice, it is very often not known whether a particular time series actually has a unit root. By way of example, scaled stock prices, that is, stock prices normalized by dividends or earnings, are often used to predict stock returns (Lamont1998). Yet, the debate as to whether stock prices actually follow a random walk dates back to at least Kendall (1953). Given this uncertainty surrounding the order of integration of stock prices themselves, it should not be surprising that the order of integration of stock prices divided by a smooth accounting variable is also uncertain.

To quantify this uncertainty, we follow Stock (1991) and construct confidence intervals for the largest autoregressive root of many explanatory variables commonly used in predictive regressions. In almost every case, the corresponding confidence intervals contain the unit root. Yet they are wide in the sense that they also contain values less than 1, which are consistent with stationarity. This paper investigates the estimation of predictive regressions in light of this uncertainty surrounding an explanatory variable's order of integration or, in other words, when the explanatory variable is nearly integrated.

We couch our statistical analysis of predictive regressions in a local‐to‐unity framework (Bobkoski1983; Chan and Wei1987; Phillips1987a; and Chan1988), where the explanatory variable is assumed to follow an autoregression with a root near to unity. That is, regardless of sample size, we are unable to distinguish a stationary specification from the unit root alternative. This inability to differentiate between stationary and nonstationary specifications captures the uncertainty surrounding an explanatory variable's order of integration. Deviations from the unit root theory are measured by a noncentrality parameter that, when its value equals zero, gives a time series with a unit root but, when the parameter's value is close to zero, gives a nearly integrated time series. The main effect of this specification is to induce noncentrality in the limiting distribution theory, resulting in conventional tests, which ignore this uncertainty, to have asymptotic sizes that exceed their nominal levels. The prevailing evidence of predictability may then simply reflect the fact that conventional tests reject too often (Elliott and Stock1994and Cavanagh, Elliott, and Stock1995). In this paper, we apply this theory to actual data drawn from financial markets and extend the local‐to‐unity analysis to the arguably more important case of long horizon predictive regressions.

By their very construction, unit root tests, such as the augmented Dickey‐Fuller (Dickey and Fuller1979) (ADF) test, have low power to reject the null hypothesis of a unit root when the underlying data is generated according to the local‐to‐unity specification. Perron (1989) demonstrates that these tests also have low power to reject the null hypothesis of a unit root when confronted by a stationary series but with a deterministic break in its level (a “crash” model) or in its trend (a “changing growth” model). In this sense, the local‐to‐unity specification is observationally equivalent to a stationary specification with breaks. Our analysis then accommodates the possibility that the explanatory variables used in predictive regressions are stationary but subject to occasional breaks. There are, in fact, good reasons to believe that many of these explanatory variables are, indeed, subject to breaks. For example, short‐term interest rates as well as the term spread are subject to the Volcker experiment between October 1979 and September 1982, while Fama and French (2002) demonstrate that there are discernable time trends in cash dividends, in particular, a sharp decline in the percentage of firms paying dividends after 1978 which may impart breaks to the dividend yield series.1

In extending the local‐to‐unity analysis to long horizon regressions, we follow Richardson and Stock (1989) and rely on an alternative asymptotic distribution theory which recognizes that, even through the sample size is large, the amount of independent information in overlapping observation may be limited. All the explanatory variables we consider—the dividend yield, the book‐to‐market ratio, the default spread, the short‐term rate of interest, and the term spread—have been previously used to forecast stock returns and are characterized, to varying degrees, by uncertainty surrounding their order of integration. After acknowledging this uncertainty, we find very little evidence of predictability at horizons greater than 1 year in the entire 1926–1994 sample period or in either the pre‐1952 or post‐1952 subsamples. In the post‐1952 subsample, however, a variety of explanatory variables, including the dividend yield as well as the term spread and the short‐term rate of interest, are seen to forecast returns at the relatively short horizons of less than 12 months. In other words, contrary to previous evidence, we find reliable evidence of predictability at short horizons rather than long horizons. We use simulation analysis to confirm that this conclusion is not due to our test methodology being incorrectly sized in small samples.

Some recent research has begun to empirically investigate stock return predictability within a local‐to‐unity framework. This research, however, concentrates solely on dividend yields and so neglects other commonly used explanatory variables. Viceira (1997), for example, investigates the stability of the dividend yield forecasting model when the dividend yield is modeled as local‐to‐unity and finds no evidence that this explanatory variable can forecast 1‐month‐ahead returns. Valkanov (2002) applies a local‐to‐unity specification to consider the dividend yield's ability to forecast stock returns at long (but not short) horizons using a test statistic whose optimal implementation relies on the long‐run restriction between dividend yields and stock returns implied by the stationary log‐linearized dynamic Gordon growth model. Valkanov finds no evidence of predictability at any long horizon (1 year through 6 years) over his entire 1927–1998 sample period. Unfortunately, this particular estimation procedure cannot be used if no such long‐run restriction holds between stock returns and the posited explanatory variable, for example, between stock returns and the default spread. Lanne (2002) also confirms the uncertainty surrounding the dividend yield's order of integration by constructing confidence intervals for this explanatory variable's largest autoregressive root. However, Lanne ignores the information contained in dividend yields by relying on the fact that returns should be stationary under the null hypothesis of no predictability. His inability to reject the stationarity of returns may then simply reflect a lack of statistical power, a conclusion confirmed by his own simulation analysis.

The plan of this paper is as follows.Section IIdetails the data used in the paper. Insection III, we confirm that it is not known with certainty whether explanatory variables commonly used in predictive regressions have a unit root or are stationary by constructing confidence intervals for the largest autoregressive root of each of the sampled explanatory variables. In almost every case, the results are consistent with this root being very near to unity if not equal to unity. It is important, therefore, to explore statistical inference in predictive regressions in light of the uncertainty surrounding a stochastic explanatory variable's order of integration. We do so insection IV, where a local‐to‐unity framework is used to explicitly recognize the effects of this uncertainty on inferences drawn in predictive regressions. We consider predicting returns one period ahead as well as at long horizons.Section Vpresents our empirical results whilesection VIconcludes the paper.

fn.p: However, while the hypothesis of stationary fluctuations around a deterministic trend function may provide an adequate empirical description of realized data, as noted by Perron (1989), it provides an unappealing model of the stochastic behavior of explanatory variables, because it implies that future changes in trend can be forecasted with certainty.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Data
sec.p: A variety of explanatory variables have been used to forecast stock returns. Rather than redefining these variables to alter their stochastic properties (for example, by stochastic detrending2or forming moving averages), we restrict our attention to these previously used explanatory variables. In addition, we confine our empirical analysis to the 1926–1994 sample period, which corresponds to the most prevalently used sample period in previous studies. As a consequence, our results are directly comparable to results available in the literature and allow us to more clearly demonstrate how inference in predictive regressions can change as the stochastic properties of the posited explanatory variable are explicitly incorporated into the estimation.

fn.p: For example, Ferson, Sarkissian, and Simin (2000) advocate the use of stochastically detrended explanatory variables in predictive regressions.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Stock Returns
sec.p: Stock returns (y t) are given by monthly log real returns of the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) value‐weighted (VW) market portfolio.3These returns are constructed by deflating the monthly returns with dividends,r,of the VW portfolio by the corresponding change in the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

fn.p: Our conclusions are qualitatively unchanged if, alternatively, we use CRSP's equal‐weighted (EW) market portfolio.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Dividend Yield

fn.p: We follow Fama and French (1988) and do not reinvest monthly dividends. Alternatively, annual dividends can be constructed by assuming monthly dividends are reinvested at prevailing monthly Treasury bill rates (Hodrick1992) or reinvested in the VW portfolio itself (Cochrane1991). Our conclusions are not affected by these alternative definitions.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: DJIA Book‐to‐Market Ratio
sec.p: We follow Pontiff and Schall (1998) and use an aggregate book‐to‐market ratio based on the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA).5The DJIA is an index of the stock prices of 30 large U.S. corporations selected to represent a cross section of U.S. industry. The December year‐end book value of the DJIA is available from 1920 to 1993. A monthly book‐to‐market ratio is constructed by dividing the most recent year's book value by the prevailing level of the DJIA. However, to ensure the use of information that was available to market participants, Pontiff and Schall do not incorporate the previous year's book value in their calculations until March of the subsequent year. We investigate the stochastic properties of the logarithm of Pontiff and Schall's DJIA book‐to‐market ratio.

fn.p: We thank Jeff Pontiff for providing us their book‐to‐market series.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: Default Spread
sec.p: The default spread is computed monthly and measured by the logarithm of the difference between the average annualized yield of bonds rated Baa by Moody's and the average annualized yield of bonds rated Aaa by Moody's. These monthly yields are averages of daily data within the month, obtained from the Federal Reserve's H.15 statistical release.

sec.label: E.
sec.title: Term Spread
sec.p: The term spread is measured by the difference between long‐term and short‐term yields on Treasury securities.6Specifically, the long‐term yield is taken to be the annualized nominal yield on a Treasury bond with maturity closest to 10 years measured at month end, obtained from the CRSP bond file.7The short‐term yield is given by the annualized nominal 3‐month Treasury bill rate (average of bid and ask) obtained from CRSP's Fama‐Bliss risk‐free rate file.

fn.p: Unlike the default spread, the term spread can be negative, so we do not use a logarithmic transform of this series.
We thank Bruno Gerard for making this data available to us.

sec.label: F.
sec.title: Short‐Term Interest Rate
sec.p: The short‐term interest rate is given by the annualized nominal 1‐month Treasury bill rate (average of bid and ask) also obtained from CRSP's Fama‐Bliss risk‐free rate file.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Unit Roots in Explanatory Variables
sec.p: Unit root tests investigate whether ρ = 1. However, unlike the information provided by the results of unit root tests, we do not simply need to know whether this root is 1 or not. Reporting the results of unit root tests or providing point estimates of ρ do not fully convey the uncertainty surrounding ρ. Confidence intervals for ρ provide a more useful summary measure of a stochastic explanatory variable's persistence by indicating a range of ρ values consistent with the observed data.

In general, confidence intervals for a parameter can be constructed from tests about that parameter. Following Stock (1991), it is natural to base confidence intervals for ρ on the augmented Dickey‐Fuller test of the hypothesis that ρ = 1. Unfortunately, the ADF statistic's distribution is highly nonnormal, so the usual approach of constructing asymptotic confidence intervals as a point estimate ±2 standard errors is not appropriate. Furthermore, we cannot rely on traditional asymptotic theory because it is discontinuous at ρ = 1.
Alternatively, we can use local‐to‐unity asymptotic theory, which models the true value of ρ as being in a 1/Tneighborhood of 1:

wherecis a fixed constant andTdenotes the sample size. Since the ADF and other unit root tests gain power at rateT,they cannot distinguish between the null hypothesis of a unit root and this alternative specification. This inability to differentiate between nonstationary and stationary specifications captures the uncertainty surrounding an explanatory variable's order of integration. Given the limiting distribution of the ADF statistic under the local‐to‐unity theory, confidence intervals for the ADF statistic8in light of the observed data can be constructed then inverted to yield confidence intervals for ρ.9

fn.p: When ρ is modeled as local‐to‐unity, there is no uniformly most powerful test of the unit root hypothesis, so test statistics other than the ADF may be inverted to give confidence intervals for ρ. See Elliott and Stock (2001) for more details.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Results
sec.p:
For each of our sampled stochastic explanatory variables,table 1presents 95% confidence intervals for ρ.10We provide results using the entire time series of data and, to investigate the robustness of our conclusions, the pre‐1952 and post‐1952 subsamples. In almost every case, these 95% confidence intervals include the unit root ρ = 1. The exceptions include the log dividend yield series over the 1926:12 to 1994:12 sample period whose upper limit of 0.996 is nearly indistinguishable from 1. While the 95% confidence interval for the term‐spread series based on the entire sample period does not contain 1, the interval based on the post‐1952 subsample does. Table 1
95% Confidence Intervals for the Largest Autoregressive Root of the Stochastic Explanatory Variables

Note.— This table provides 95% confidence intervals for the largest autoregressive root ρ of stochastic explanatory variables typically used in predictive regressions. The explanatory variables used are Dividend yield, Default spread, Book to market, Term spread, and Short‐term rate. Dividend yield is the log real dividend yield, constructed as in Fama and French (1988). Default spread is the log of the difference between monthly averaged annualized yields of bonds rated Baa and Aaa by Moody’s. Book‐to‐market is the log of Pontiff and Schall’s (1998) Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) book‐to‐market ratio. Term spread is the difference between annualized yields of Treasury bonds with maturity closest to 10 years at month end and 3‐month Treasury bills. Short‐term rate is the nominal 1‐month Treasury bill rate. The augmented Dickey‐Fuller statistic is denoted ADF, and we follow Ng and Perron (1995) in determining the maximum lag lengthk.

Confidence intervals for ρ based on the entire time series of observations tend to be narrower than those based on the subsamples with their fewer number of observations. However, even confidence intervals based on the pre‐1952 sample period, which contain the fewest number of observations, are still relatively narrow about unity. For example, the 95% confidence interval for ρ using the log default spread series over the 1926:12 to 1951:12 sample period is (0.984, 1.015).

fn.p: We use the sequential pretesting method of Ng and Perron (1995) to determine the maximum lag lengthk.This method selectskonly after testing sequentially that the coefficients on additional lags,k + 1 and longer, are statistically insignificant.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Predictive Regressions
sec.p: The results oftable 1are consistent with the measure of persistence ρ for stochastic explanatory variables typically used in predictive regressions being very near to unity if not actually equal to unity. Given that it is not known with certainty whether an explanatory variable has a unit root or is stationary, it is important then that we recognize the effects of this uncertainty on inferences drawn in predictive regressions. We now explore statistical inference in predictive regressions within the local‐to‐unity framework. We first investigate the consequences of using nearly integrated regressors to predict returns one period ahead and then to predict over longer horizons.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: One‐Period Returns
sec.p:
We consider a predictive regression in which stock returns,y t, are regressed against the lagged values of a stochastic explanatory variable,x
t−1, for example, the lagged log dividend yield
where \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $q( L) =\sum_{j=0}^{p}q_{j}L^{j},q_{0}=1$ \end{document} , with all of the roots ofq(L) assumed to lie outside the unit circle and ε2t is a martingale difference sequence. The assumed dynamics ofu 2t permit serial correlation in the residuals of the predictive regression.

Of course, different values of the explanatory variable's largest autoregressive root, ρ inequation (1), have substantially different implications for the stochastic behavior of the explanatory variable, in particular, whether ρ=1 and the explanatory variable is nonstationary12or ρ < 1 and the explanatory variable is stationary.13

To capture the uncertainty surrounding an explanatory variable's order of integration, we nest ρ in a 1/Tneighborhood of 1, \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\rho =1+c/ T$ \end{document} , wherecis a constant, and investigate the resultant implications on testing whether β = 0 inequation (2). In particular, it has been shown that, under the local‐to‐unity specification,t β, thet‐statistic testing β = 0 inequation (2), andt ρ, the ADF statistic testing ρ = 1 inequation (1)have the following joint limiting distribution under the null hypothesis that β = 0 and ρ = 1:

Asymptotically, only when δ = 0 ist βnormally distributed independent oft ρ. For nonzero δ,t βhas a nonstandard distribution that depends on bothcand δ.15In other words, when δ ≠ 0, information about the explanatory variable, in particular, uncertainty about its order of integration, should be explicitly taken into account when making statistical inferences about β and concluding whether returns are predictable or not.

If we simply ignore the possibility of a unit root in the stochastic explanatory variable when δ ≠ 0, then the normal distribution provides a poor approximation to the appropriate nonstandard distribution and results in substantial size distortions in tests of the predictive regression.16Furthermore, a two‐step procedure in which we first pretest for a unit root inequation (1), then use standard or nonstandard critical values for inference inequation (2), depending on whether a unit root is rejected or not, respectively, also produces large size distortions in testing whether β = 0 inequation (2).17

We can, however, provide asymptotically valid tests of β = 0 inequation (2)that do not depend oncby constructing Bonferroni intervals for β. These are confidence intervals for β in which the dependence oncis eliminated by invoking the Bonferroni inequality. While Bonferroni intervals are conservative, we follow Cavanagh et al. (1995) and subsequently adjust these intervals so that their nominal size equals a desired level asymptotically.

fn.p:
That is, 2π times the spectral density matrix of the error termsu
t evaluated at frequency zero.

Ferson et al. (2000) also explore the implications of a persistent explanatory variable on the properties of predictive regressions. However, they treat expected returns as unobservable and, more important, demonstrate that, if expected returns are persistent then a spurious regression may obtain if realized returns are regressed against an unrelated but persistent explanatory variable. In contrast, we assume returns, both expected and realized, are related to the persistent explanatory variable.
See, for example, Elliott and Stock (1994) or Lanne (2002).

Lanne (2002) relies on the nearly integrated nature of the dividend yield series to conclude that a standardt‐test is, in general, inappropriate to assess statistical significance in a dividend yield regression. Rather than using the appropriate but nonstandardt βdistribution, Lanne argues that, under the null hypothesis of no predictability, that is, β = 0 in equation (2), returns should be stationary; and he uses the Kwiatkowski, Phillips, Schmidt, and Shin (KPSS) (1992) test to investigate the stationarity properties of returns. Consequently, Lanne uses no information contained in the dividend yield series to assess whether returns are predictable or not and, in essence, tests whether returns exhibit weak‐form efficiency as opposed to semi‐strong‐form efficiency.
For example, Elliot and Stock report Monte Carlo evidence that, for ρ = 0.975, δ = −0.9, andT = 100, a one‐sidedZ‐test with nominal level of 5% actually has a rejection rate of 23%.

For example, Cavanagh et al. provide Monte Carlo evidence that, forc = −20, δ = −0.9, andT = 500, the corresponding second step test with nominal level of 5% actually has a rejection rate of 37%. Intuitively, under the local‐to‐unity model, the first step test cannot reject the null hypothesis of a unit root,c = 0, with probability 1 asymptotically, even though ρ may, in fact, be large but less than 1,c < 0. To the extent that in the first step the stochastic explanatory variable cannot asymptotically be classified correctly, the resultant poor critical values result in incorrect inference regarding β in the second step.

Valkanov (2002) argues that, in the case of dividend yield regressions, a consistent estimator ofccan be obtained by exploiting the long‐run restriction between returns and dividend yields implied by the log‐linearized dynamic Gordon model of Campbell and Shiller (1988). This result, however, depends on the assumed stationarity of the dividend yield process, in which case the log‐linearization is carried out around a constant mean and the resultant approximation is accurate. If the dividend yield is not stationary, this approximation is inaccurate as will be Valkanov's estimator ofcbecause the mean of the dividend yield process is no longer time invariant.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Long Horizon Returns
sec.p:
It is common in predictive regressions to useK > 1 period returns,y
t (K), where
rather than one‐period returns to increase statistical power and improve statistical efficiency. We now assume that long horizon returns are regressed against the lagged values of a stochastic explanatory variable \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $x_{t-1}$ \end{document} :
The following lemma provides the results needed to prove our distributional results. In what follows, → and ⇒ denote convergence in probability and convergence in distribution, respectively.
Proof.See theappendix.
Proof.See theappendix.

To the extent that inference in long horizon regressions depends critically on the parameter θ, given the regression horizonKand the sample sizeT,the appropriate simulated asymptotic distribution relying on the resultant value of θ must be used to correctly assess statistical significance. In particular, as the horizonKis increased for a fixed sample sizeT,the appropriate distribution changes as θ correspondingly increases. Using the same distribution to assess significance at different horizons for a fixed sample size may lead to a potentially sizeable loss of statistical power.

fn.p: For expositional purposes we assume, without loss of generality, that α(K) = 0 and μ = 0.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Empirical Results
sec.p:
In this section, we estimate predictive regressions, both one‐period as well as long horizon, and assess the statistical significance of predictability once uncertainty surrounding a stochastic explanatory variable's order of integration is explicitly taken into account. In particular,table 4presents point estimates, \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\hat{\beta }( K) $ \end{document} , traditional 95% confidence intervals as well as 95% Bonferroni confidence intervals when CRSP VW returns are regressed against the dividend yield, default spread, book‐to‐market ratio, the term spread, and the short‐term rate of interest, respectively. In constructing these confidence intervals, we recognize that the residualsu 1t andu 2t may be autocorrelated and the corresponding estimated long‐run correlation coefficient \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\hat{\delta }$ \end{document} takes this into account.24

Note.— This table provides 95% traditional (in parentheses) and Bonferroni (in square brackets) confidence intervals to assess the statistical significance of the slope coefficient β in regressing long horizonK = 1, 3, 12, 24, 36, and 48 months) log real returns of the CRSP VW index against a stochastic explanatory variable, assuming the explanatory variable’s largest autoregressive root ρ is characterized by a local‐to‐unity specification ρ = 1 + c/T,wherecis a nuisance parameter andTdenotes the sample size. The explanatory variables used are Dividend yield, Default spread, Book‐to‐market, Term spread, and Short‐term rate. These variables are described intable 1. The Bonferroni intervals are subsequently adjusted so that their nominal size equals 5% asymptotically. The sample correlation coefficient \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\hat{\delta }$ \end{document} is estimated nonparametrically, recognizing that the 1‐month‐ahead predictive regression’s estimated disturbances and the estimated disturbances of the autoregression in the explanatory variables may themselves be autocorrelated. Here, * denotes evidence against the null hypothesis of no predictability using traditional confidence intervals, while † denotes evidence against the null hypothesis of no predictability using Bonferroni confidence intervals.

For example, consistent with the results of Campbell et al. (1997), when we ignore uncertainty surrounding the order of integration of the log dividend yield series, we see, both in the entire sample and the subsamples, evidence consistent with dividend yields reliably forecasting long horizon CRSP VW returns.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Small‐Sample Properties
sec.p: The fact that we find reliable evidence of predictability at short horizons and not at long horizons may suggest that our estimation methodology is not properly sized in small samples. As a result, it is important to investigate the small‐sample properties of our estimation methodology. Conducting this Monte Carlo analysis requires an underlying data generating process (DGP). We use actual data to calibrate the assumed DGP. In particular, we focus on the returns‐log dividend yield system.25

Table 5reports the finite‐sample size of the Bonferroni test at a given horizonK,defined as the proportion of the corresponding 10,000 simulations that reject the null hypothesis of no predictability using these 95% Bonferroni confidence intervals when no predictability is actually present. Note that this test is properly sized at allKvalues, so our reported evidence of predictability at short but not at long horizons does not appear to be an artifact of the Bonferroni test being systematically oversized in small samples. Table 5
Finite Sample Size Properties of the Bonferroni Test
HorizonK
Autocovariance Lag Length Equal toK− 1 Autocovariance Lag Length Determined by Newey‐West Procedure
1 month 0.045 0.042
12 months 0.046 0.048
36 months 0.048 0.153
60 months 0.044 0.324
120 months 0.046 0.389
Note.— This table summarizes the size properties in finite samples of a Bonferroni test whose asymptotic size is 5%. The null hypothesis being tested is no predictability. The underlying data is generated from a bivariate vector autoregression estimated using actual monthly real VW returns and log dividend yields over the 1926:12 to 1994:12 sample period, imposing the restriction that the log dividend yield does not enter the one‐period returns equation. For each return horizonK,we report the finite‐sample size of the Bonferroni test, defined as the proportion of 10,000 simulations in which the Bonferroni test rejects the null hypothesis of no predictability. In calculating the Newey‐West correctedt‐statistics, we explicitly incorporate the data overlap inherent in long horizon regressions by setting the autocovariance lag length equal toK − 1 (second column) and, alternatively, using Newey‐West’s (1994) automatic bandwith procedure to determine this lag length (third column).

Alternatively, we may conduct statistical inference relying on Newey‐West correctedt‐statistics calculated using Newey‐West's (1994) automatic bandwith selection procedure and thereby ignoring that the data overlap inherent in long horizon regressions increases with the return horizonK. 26Hence, θ, the overlap expressed as a fraction of the sample size, is essentially fixed throughout. As can be seen inTable 5, the resultant test is grossly oversized in small samples. Hence, tests that neglect the increasing overlap inherent in long horizon regressions tend to overreject the null hypothesis of no predictability, especially at longer horizons. Intuitively, if θ is fixed and relatively small, then long horizon regressions are equivalent to short horizon regressions, where there is indeed minimal data overlap.

fn.p: Although the use of our other predictors gives qualitatively similar results.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Researchers in finance frequently rely on nearly integrated explanatory variables to predict returns. While it is often acknowledged that an explanatory variable like the dividend yield is close to being integrated, it is typically done so only with the caveat that the corresponding empirical results should be interpreted with some caution. This paper, by contrast, details how researchers can explicitly conduct inference in one‐period ahead and long horizon predictive regressions when they are unsure of an explanatory variable's order of integration. The importance of conducting inference in this case is underscored by the fact that confidence intervals for the largest autoregressive root of commonly used explanatory variables are more often than not consistent with uncertainty surrounding their order of integration.

The prevailing evidence regarding return predictability is that its statistical significance is much more pronounced at longer return horizons. The argument is made, at least intuitively, that relying on longer as opposed to shorter horizon returns minimizes the noise inherent in returns and so allows the posited predictive relation to potentially be seen more clearly. In this paper, to the contrary, it is precisely at return horizons of less than 1 year, that we find reliable evidence once the local‐to‐unity behavior of commonly used explanatory variables is taken into account. This suggests that the previous evidence reported at long horizons simply reflects that conventional statistics overreject the null hypothesis of no predictability when the persistent behavior of the explanatory variables is not explicitly taken into account.

list-item.p: The proof for (a) and (b) are standard and can be found, for example, in Phillips (1987a).
Statement (f) is proven easily by applying (a), (e), and the continuous mapping theorem.

To prove statement (a), multiply the numerator and denominator of \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\hat{\beta }( K) $ \end{document} byT -2and apply (b) and (c) of the lemma.

To prove statement (c), multiply the numerators and denominators of \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\hat{\beta }( K) $ \end{document} byT -2and apply (e) and (f) of the lemma.

To prove statement (d), multiply the numerators and denominators of \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\hat{t}_{\hat{\beta }( K) }$ \end{document} byT -2and use the definition ofU(r) and the continuous mapping theorem.

fn.p: Since these details are complicated, we do not present them for expositional purposes. They are, however, available on request from the author.
